item.title: California Fires Live Updates: State Hit by 10,000 Lightning Strikes in 72 Hours
item.description: Fast-moving fires are spreading across Northern California, with wind-whipped flames forcing people to flee their homes.
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Finally the Country Sees Us’: Some Women of Color Cheer Harris’s Rise
item.description: In Kamala Harris, many women of color see a successful vice-presidential candidate standing atop a mountain of firsts — but also facing a gender and racial minefield.
item.dc:creator: Audra D. S. Burch, Jennifer Medina and Evan Nicole Brown
item.media:credit: Maria Alejandra Cardona for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We want our leaders to make Black lives a priority and to shift the systems that do not serve us and were not made for us,” Krystina François said.

item.title: Reopening Florida Schools Is Likened to Military Operation
item.description: Gov. Ron DeSantis, faced with reluctance by local schools to reopen during the coronavirus pandemic, compared it to the campaign to get Osama bin Laden.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei and Manny Fernandez
item.media:credit: Octavio Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Katie Stallings setting up her second-grade classroom at MacFarlane Park Elementary in Tampa, Fla. Most Florida schools must offer in-person instruction by the end of the month.

item.title: The California Wildfires in Pictures
item.description: Photographers are on the ground capturing the fast-moving fires that are spreading across the state.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times

item.title: Flashback/Flash-Forward
item.description: Hillary Clinton’s D.N.C. appearance tonight is a reminder of how the party has changed since 2016.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times

item.title: Three in Masks Sought in Denver House Fire That Killed Five
item.description: Detectives hope that a chilling picture of people in dark hoods and white masks leads them to those who set fire to a house this month, killing five members of a Senegalese family.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Detectives are hoping to identify the three people pictured here in connection with the fatal fire.

item.title: Cheering From the Den During a Virtual Convention
item.description: Some die-hard Democratic delegates long for an in-person event. “It feels so lonesome when you don’t have all the crowds,” said an 89-year-old convention veteran.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: David Walter Banks for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Rosalind Wyman’s house in Los Angeles, the Democratic National Convention is blaring from television sets in four rooms. “I have it so that I won’t miss anything,” she said.

item.title: U.S. Suspends Bilateral Agreements With Hong Kong, Escalating Tensions With China
item.description: The actions are part of the Trump administration’s broader efforts to punish China for its attempts to stifle political dissent in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Pranshu Verma
item.media:description: The three agreements cover the transfer of fugitives and convicted prisoners as well as reciprocal tax exemptions on income from international shipping.

item.title: Ex-F.B.I. Lawyer Pleads Guilty to Doctoring Email in Russia Inquiry
item.description: The former official admitted that he had intentionally inserted words into the text of the email, which discussed past relations between the C.I.A. and Carter Page, the former Trump campaign adviser.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: The F.B.I. headquarters in Washington. The case of Kevin E. Clinesmith, who worked with the agency’s Trump-Russia investigation team, has drawn heightened political attention.

item.title: Kansas Democrat, 19, Who Admitted to Revenge Porn, Ekes Out Primary Win
item.description: Aaron Coleman defeated a seven-term incumbent for a state House seat by 14 votes, alarming Democrats who worry he will hurt other candidates in the general election.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:description: Aaron Coleman, 19, narrowly won a Democratic primary for a seat in the Kansas Legislature. His acknowledgement that he harassed girls online when he was in middle school has alarmed state Democrats.

item.title: The Trump campaign's latest YouTube ads have been seen 40 million times.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti

item.title: Obama Returns to the D.N.C. With a Chance to Rescue His Legacy From Trump
item.description: After four years watching his achievements being dismantled, he has almost as much at stake as his party’s nominee, Joe Biden, does.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: Former President Barack Obama’s determination to see President Trump defeated may be as powerful, or even more so, than his desire to elevate Joseph R. Biden Jr.

item.title: When the V.P. Is ‘the Woman’s Spot’
item.description: 1984. 2008. 2020. What have American voters and political commentators learned in 36 years from Ferraro to Palin to Harris?
item.dc:creator: Amanda Hess
item.media:description: When Walter Mondale tapped Geraldine Ferraro to be his running mate in 1984, she was judged as the most interesting thing about him.

item.title: Doug Emhoff is a contender to become the country’s first Second Gentleman.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris in Wilmington, Del., with her husband, Douglas Emhoff, after her first news conference with Joseph R. Biden Jr. as his running mate.

item.title: This Trawler’s Haul: Evidence That Antibodies Block the Coronavirus
item.description: Three crew members aboard were spared when the virus spread through the boat. They were the only ones who had antibodies at the beginning of the trip.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: The American Dynasty, carrying 122 crew, returned to shore in May after 18 days at sea when a crew member became ill enough to need hospitalization.

item.title: QAnon Groups Removed by Facebook
item.description: The social network also said it was restricting another 1,950 groups, 440 pages on Facebook and more than 10,000 accounts on Instagram related to the conspiracy group.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: John Rudoff/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Facebook’s action on Wednesday was its most sweeping against the QAnon conspiracy theory, which supporters promote with Q signs.

item.title: Amazon halts sales of shirts that used a derogatory term to refer to Kamala Harris.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris, the Democratic nominee for vice president.

item.title: Slade Gorton, Who Was Voted Out of Senate and Then Back In, Dies at 92
item.description: A “passionate moderate” Republican from Washington State, he served three nonconsecutive terms as a friend to its industries, from logging to tech.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: Senator Slate Gorton speaking to local business leaders in Olympia, Wash., in 1999. A Republican first elected on the coattails of Ronald Reagan’s presidential landslide in 1980, he called himself a “passionate moderate.”

item.title: Trump urges Goodyear boycott after report that his campaign gear was banned at a plant.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Political apparel, like the hats worn by these Trump supporters at a Wisconsin rally this week, has been forbidden at a Goodyear tire plant in Kansas.

item.title: She Was More Than Just the ‘Most Beautiful Suffragist’
item.description: Exalted as a martyr to the cause of women’s suffrage, Inez Milholland later fell largely from view. But Jeanine Michna-Bales, a history-obsessed artist, is determined to change that.
item.dc:creator: Meredith Mendelsohn
item.category: Standing Together: Photographs of Inez Milholland's Final Campaign for Women's Suffrage (Exhibit)

item.title: What Kind of Second Gentleman Would Doug Emhoff Be?
item.description: Kamala Harris’s lawyer husband is adoring on Instagram, proud of telling their love story and seems to relish life as a campaign spouse.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris in Wilmington, Del., with her husband, Douglas Emhoff, after her first news conference with Joseph R. Biden Jr. as his running mate.

item.title: Biden Said, ‘Most Cops Are Good.’ But Progressives Want Systemic Change.
item.description: Joe Biden’s comment at the convention that “most cops are good” and that the bad ones need to be prosecuted struck an array of activists as discordant at a moment when many are calling for transformational change.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and John Eligon
item.media:description: Democrats who want to defund or abolish police departments can move the needle, as evidenced by efforts to trim police budgets that, not long ago, seemed unlikely.

item.title: Jill Biden offers a different model for first lady, our fashion critic writes.
item.media:credit: Democratic National Convention, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Jill Biden spoke during the Democratic National Convention on Tuesday from the Wilmington, Del., high school where she once taught.

item.title: Trump Cites the V.A. as a Central Achievement. But Troubles Simmer.
item.description: The department’s long litany of problems has left some questioning why President Trump is trying to make his record there a centerpiece of his re-election campaign.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and Robert L. Wilkie, the secretary of veterans affairs, at the White House last month. There has been little improvement over the last four years in some of the agency’s systemic problems.

item.title: Colleges Closing: University Outbreaks and Parental Angst
item.description: Coronavirus clusters have been linked to fraternities, sororities, and off-campus parties.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
item.media:description: The Bear Trap’s rooftop bar on the Strip, part of the University of Alabama’s bar scene, in Tuscaloosa, Ala.

item.title: The Affordable Care Act, and Trump’s push to repeal it, become a focus at the Democratic convention.
item.dc:creator: Andy Newman

item.title: Democrats want to know how a Trump megadonor became postmaster general.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: Chuck Schumer, the Senate minority leader, called on the Postal Service to release the firm that helped select Louis DeJoy as postmaster general from a nondisclosure agreement.

item.title: What the Newly Approved Democratic Party Platform Actually Says
item.description: It’s a largely symbolic document that broadly outlines the party’s agenda. It doesn’t make everyone happy.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Democratic Party platform covers topics including the response to the coronavirus pandemic, health care, the economy, climate change, immigration and criminal justice.

item.title: McConnell wants a Lincoln-Douglas-style debate with his Democratic challenger.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos

item.title: Elizabeth Warren, who speaks tonight, has challenged Wall Street. What will that mean for her future?
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Elizabeth Warren is Washington D.C. in July.

item.title: Kanye West should be kept off Wisconsin’s ballot, election agency staff members say.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:description: Kanye West at a rally in support of his presidential bid last month in North Charleston, S.C.

item.title: House candidate arrested on domestic violence charges loses after a recount.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Lt. Don Crabtree/Wethersfield Police Department, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Thomas Gilmer

item.title: Teachers, Tell Us Your Difficult Decisions About In-Person Learning
item.description: We want to hear how educators are approaching the upcoming semester.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: An assistant helped a student as in-person learning resumes at an elementary school in Phoenix on Monday.

item.title: Clyburn compares the stakes of the 2020 election to Lincoln’s candidacy in 1860.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative James E. Clyburn is widely credited with resuscitating former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s candidacy.

item.title: Apple Reaches $2 Trillion, Punctuating Big Tech’s Grip
item.description: Apple is the first U.S. company to hit that value, a staggering ascent that began in the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas

item.title: Fox News hosts and guests offer a skeptical take on the convention.
item.dc:creator: Kathleen Gray
item.media:credit: Erin Scott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Ted Cruz on Capitol Hill in March. Mr. Cruz criticized former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Tuesday night as lifeless, calling him “a dead guy that they roll out there.”

item.title: Representative Ross Spano of Florida loses Republican primary.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Michael D. Shear and Andy Newman
item.media:credit: Michael Brochstein/Sipa USA)(Sipa via AP Images
item.media:description: Ross Spano lost his fight to continue representing Florida’s 15th Congressional District by two percentage points.

item.title: Suburban women take on Trump with a letter-writing campaign.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor

item.title: As the D.N.C. unfolds, Trump reprises the grimmest language of the 2016 campaign.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: President Trump spoke on immigration and border security during a campaign rally in Yuma, Ariz.

item.title: Blood Plasma Treatment for Covid-19 Now on Hold at F.D.A.
item.description: Government health leaders including Dr. Francis S. Collins and Dr. Anthony S. Fauci urged caution last week, citing weak data from the country’s largest plasma study.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland, Sharon LaFraniere and Sheri Fink
item.media:description: Javier Alvarez donating his plasma at Houston Methodist Hospital in July after his grandmother died from the virus.

item.title: Talking to Long Beach’s Mayor, a ‘Next Generation’ Democrat
item.description: Wednesday: Mayor Robert Garcia of Long Beach discusses losing his parents to Covid-19 and speaking at the Democratic National Convention.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Jeff Gritchen/The Orange County Register, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mayor Robert Garcia of Long Beach, Calif.

item.title: Biden’s champions on foreign policy push for a return of the old guard.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck, Matt Flegenheimer and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Democratic National Convention, via Getty Images
item.media:description: John Kerry said that “America deserves a president who is looked up to, not laughed at.”

item.title: The Democrats gave Biden the nomination he has sought since 1988.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin
item.media:credit: Democratic National Convention, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at the second night of the virtual Democratic National Convention.

item.title: Here’s how to watch Night 3 of the convention.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Perez, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, spoke at the Wisconsin Center on Tuesday, the second day of the Democratic National Convention.

item.title: Democrats Set Aside Their Differences
item.description: Night 2 of the Democratic National Convention made clear why Joe Biden is now the nominee.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Nick Corasaniti

item.title: The Record Market, Explained
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Sanam Yar
item.media:description: Much of the stock market’s success has been the result of a run-up in value for few big technology companies such as Apple.

item.title: Covid-19 Live Updates: Opening of U.S. Education System Brings Strike Threats, New Cases and Improvisation
item.description: South Africa’s efforts to contain the virus are tainted by corruption. Top U.S. health officials intervened just as the F.D.A. was prepared to issue an emergency authorization for plasma as a virus treatment.

item.title: The Untold Story of the Black Marines Charged With Mutiny at Sea
item.description: Racial strife aboard a Navy ship left three men facing the threat of the death penalty. They became little more than statistics in the military’s dismal record of race relations in the Vietnam era.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Alabama Reopening Universities as Virus Looms
item.description: The state is betting its robust student testing and technology program will be enough to hinder campus outbreaks, even as universities in other states abruptly close.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:description: As part of a statewide campus reopening program, the University of Alabama at Birmingham has set up 13 virus testing sites for students, even as universities outside the state have abruptly closed.

item.title: Why Work From Home When You Can Work From Barbados, Bermuda or … Estonia?
item.description: Several countries with fragile tourist economies have started to offer visas that allow foreign nationals to live and work for a period of at least six months.
item.dc:creator: Charu Suri
item.media:credit: Steve Legato for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lamin Ngobeh, a high-school teacher in Delaware, plans to move temporarily to Barbados in September.

item.title: Two Marines Who Once Stood Up to Discrimination Reunite
item.description: ‘All we tried to do was segregate ourselves, because we weren’t being treated fairly.’
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kennedi Carter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harry Wilson (left) and Alexander Holmes were deployed aboard the U.S.S. Sumter in 1972 when fighting broke out between white and Black Marines.

item.title: Hillary Clinton’s Bittersweet Return to the Democratic Convention
item.description: The party’s 2016 standard-bearer will return to the stage on Wednesday to promote Joseph R. Biden Jr. and confer her legacy on Kamala Harris, the vice-presidential nominee.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer and Glenn Thrush
item.media:description: For Hillary Clinton, this political moment is both a reminder of a job some allies still maintain was unfairly taken from her and the wave of feminist activism sparked by her loss.
